docs.snippet: NEUMAN--Shirley (Bilus), February 16, 1919. Wife of the late Edward. Mother of Barbara Masket (Samuel) and Andrea Rubin (Mark). Grandmother of Seth Masket (Vivian), Harris Masket (Sirena), Stefani Wulkan (Josh) and Eric Rubin (little Andy). GG of ...
docs.lead_paragraph: NEUMAN--Shirley (Bilus), February 16, 1919. Wife of the late Edward. Mother of Barbara Masket (Samuel) and Andrea Rubin (Mark). Grandmother of Seth Masket (Vivian), Harris Masket (Sirena), Stefani Wulkan (Josh) and Eric Rubin (little Andy). GG of Eli, Delilah, Adam, Sadie, Reggie and Oscar. Sister of Herbert Bilus and dear companion of Samuel Geltman. A tower of strength to all who knew her. Shirley's Place is now officially closed. Service Wednesday February 18, 11:30am, Gutterman and Musicant, Hackensack, NJ.

docs.snippet: 9 P.M. (Starz) THE VISITOR (2008) In the role that has earned him an Oscar nomination for best actor, Richard Jenkins (above left, with Haaz Sleiman)  plays a widowed, depressed professor of economics at Connecticut College who finds that his Manh...
docs.lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Starz) THE VISITOR (2008) In the role that has earned him an Oscar nomination for best actor, Richard Jenkins (above left, with Haaz Sleiman) plays a widowed, depressed professor of economics at Connecticut College who finds that his Manhattan apartment has been illegally rented to a drummer from Syria (Mr. Sleiman) and his Senegalese girlfriend (Danai Gurira). Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said that Tom McCarthy, the film's director, ''with impressive grace and understatement'' resists ''potential triteness and phony uplift.'' Mr. Scott called Mr. Jenkins's performance one of ''quiet precision'' in which he ''manages at once to deflect and to earn the audience's sympathy, and to convey an inner transformation brought about by a shy, unselfish engagement with other people.'' NOON (13) THE OPEN MIND Jonathan F. Fanton, president of the MacArthur Foundation, discusses his organization's patterns of giving.

docs.snippet: Imagine our surprise. Not twelve steps from the elevator door on the 13th floor of the downtown criminal courts building here stood Marina Zenovich. She would be the filmmaker whose documentary, "Roman Polanski: Wanted and Desired," did not make t...
docs.lead_paragraph: Imagine our surprise. Not 12 steps from the elevator door at the downtown criminal courts building here stood Marina Zenovich. She would be the filmmaker whose documentary, "Roman Polanski: Wanted and Desired," did not make the short list of Oscar-contenders this year, despite excellent reviews and churning up a still-raging storm over alleged wrong-doing by the justice system from which Mr. Polanski fled to France. He did so after pleading guilty to having wrongful sex with a minor three decades ago.
docs.abstract: Imagine our surprise. Not twelve steps from the elevator door on the 13th floor of the downtown criminal courts building here stood Marina Zenovich. She would be the filmmaker whose documentary, "Roman Polanski: Wanted and Desired," did not make the short list of Oscar-contenders this year.
